It looks good, hip and people are coming in this means a better environment. Last but not least the new waitresses are fab! Great service will do wonders... (Insert curse word here) wonders for the entire atmosphere of an establishment! Someone who can confidently make recommendations, is polite, and socially aware of when to stop by the table and when to stay away- Perfecto! I rarely give out five stars, but here's my prediction... You are on the right path Blackies... as you can see, I'm  a fan of the revamp... previously not so much, but now yes!Areas of improvement: Never run out of broccoli, ever! Advertise that the menu makes adjustments for food allergies. Have dessert that includes fresh fruit. There's nothing like fresh fruit desserts to encourage people to have dessert.You will find me by the window a bottle of wine, appetizer, and dinner. Go ahead and say hi.... I don't bite unless you are on my fork! Grrrrrr ;) ha ha

53.description: Three stars for now until I have their food. Good overall bar for a beer or two. Nothing fancy. Large outdoor sidewalk seating. A few televisions... The place needs some freshening up. Long bar area for about 12 people.. Some high tables and a pool table.

30.description: Right across the street from my apartment, I'm surprised it took me so long to finally hit. It's a pretty neat little bar, but the service could be better. Awfully slow when you're in a group with 5+ people, even more if you're each on separate checks. And a little too pricey to have to deal with that type of slow service. But, the food and drinks are all good. Everyone in the group seemed to thoroughly enjoy the food, and it's not like we were even really in a rush to get out. It's the perfect spot if you want to sit for hours and talk over food/drinks, but not if you have other, time-dependent plans for the evening. We loved that they had a jukebox and a half-way decent selection of music, and even then, the music level isn't too loud for conversation.

46.description: I had the salmon burger and fries here. I was excited for the entree, but unfortunately it took around 45 minutes for the food just to come out. On top of this, I'm pretty sure the burger was missing some dressing or something, it tasted very bland - not good at all. Overall, I haven't tried the beer, but when it comes to food I probably wouldn't return.

1.description: I am not sure why it has taken me this long to write a review for Blackie's, but better late than never. I started going to Blackie's last summer when I moved closer to the Loop/South Loop area and I love everything about it!Food: Great bar food and I always find myself wanting to try something new here because there are so many options. Prices are very reasonable as well.Drinks: I haven't gone to Blackie's without having a drink, but I think I fell in love with this place on my first visit when I tried their WATERMELON SHOTS! They were strong, tasty, and only $1! On my birthday, I visited Blackie's and just had a few standard drinks, until I looked at the drink menu. I was able to order a Frozen Mango Margarita! I am the pickiest person when it comes to Margaritas, and used to only drink them at Ceasar's in Lakeview, but this drink was excellent and large. Overall, Blackie's is my preference for drinks because of the quality and reasonable prices.Service: The service is great and everyone is really friendly. There aren't any servers or bartenders who give off the impression that they don't want to be there or that their customers are burdensome. Great hospitality!Atmosphere: It is usually quiet when I visit, but I enjoy that. It isn't the typical douchey River North atmosphere that many desire and I probably appreciate that the most. When I have cocktails and food, I prefer a relaxed atmosphere and I definitely had this at Blackie's.

55.description: Sweet patio! Lots of people walking around and dog watching. Good food. The Rueben and Salmon sandwich have never failed us. Good drinks, staff is really nice. Kinda quiet and laid back but it works.

9.description: I absolutely love Blackies and can't even count how many times I have been here! Love love love this place! First off the food is great! They have changed their menu and it's even better!! By far.. My favorite for an appetizer is the pork/polenta! You have to try it! I also really enjoy the baby arugula salad! As for entrees.. Honestly everything is very good! My favorite is the burgers!As for ambience it is casual/ bar/ restaurant. It's in a perfect location! In the summer you can enjoy eating outside and bring your dog! This is truly a Chicago Gem! There is something about this place that I just absolutely love!

26.description: Simple bar food with a simple atmosphere.  We live just around the corner from Blackie's and know that it will always be a place we can turn to for a quick beer and a basic bite.Nothing about Blackie's necessarily stands out, but that's not to say anything about it is terrible either.  The wait staff is always friendly and welcoming and provide us with what we need quickly.If I would suggest anything, however, go on a Sunday for their brunch.  Worth any wait.

25.description: Love this place. Love the atmosphere. Would definitely come back. You can't beat a $6 pitcher. Even if it's not your favorite beer. $20 minimum bar tab was an annoyance. Would've been a problem if I wasn't able to drink more than most. Would definitely come back

12.description: I'd been here once or twice for lunch with a colleague. However, this time, my husband and I met friends here for dinner before going to the Jazz Showcase, which is just a block or two away.The food was terrific! I had the burger with everything on it--delicious, with a side salad that I chose instead of fries--and my husband had the Mason Dixon burger (with slaw, pulled pork) with chips (instead of fries). Our friends had the massive Reuben (which looked fabulous--and huge) and the tacos. Everything was delicious and very reasonably-priced. I think we may venture over here even when we are not at work!

59.description: Bars today really are different than they used to be. A lot of them started serving gourmet food and it really took off. Walking into Blackie's it looks like your typical Irish/English bar akin to Billy Goat Tavern. It just has that look of a place with a lot of history behind it, but who cares? It's lunch time and we're ready to eat!This place is conveniently located in busy downtown Chicago, within in spitting distance of a lot of businesses where employees work their butts off which gives them an immense hunger. Talk about prime real estate. Me and my co-worker came here at that dreadful noonish time where most restaurants would have a line out the door, but luckily when we got here we found a seat almost immediately. Looking over the menu there were many tasty sounding treats, but I decided on the salmon mini-burgers and a lemonade. Service was pretty fast, I got my order in about 10 minutes, but my co-worker's took about 20 for some reason. Within that time we were having a conversation one minute then I noticed the chattering getting louder and louder. Next thing you know I look around and the place is PACKED! The salmon burgers looked fantastic and came with a side of waffle fries. We asked for some condiments like honey mustard, which they gladly provided free of charge. Another good bonus was the free refills on our drinks. The entire time the waitress was nice and courteous, the second my glass got even close to empty she was already there with another. Although the salmon wasn't cooked to perfection, it was pretty close and didn't take much away from the already well seasoned fish. The waffle fries were great as well. What surprised me the most though was that for what would typically be considered "gourmet" food, the prices weren't your typical prices, but still pretty high considering it's just burgers and fries. Looking forward to trying it out again!

21.description: This is easily one of the best places for food and drink in the South Loop, and one of the best patios in the city.  "What's so special about it," you ask.  "It looks like just a normal sidewalk seating area."  Let me tell you:  It's the service.  You'll get excellent service out here, no matter how long you're chillin' with your chums.  Sounds so simple, but so few places can deliver like Blackie's.  Plus, the patio is so inviting, other patrons are liable to join your little sidewalk chat.  It's like they moved the fundamentals of a neighborhood pub outside!  If you're drinking, the prices definitely entice you to prolong your afternoon chill-session.  Highly recommended, for brunch, lunch, dinner, and chill-sessions!

17.description: Casual Americana Pub Style Fare at it's finest!Came into Blackie's South Loop on the recommendation of a local. **Tip of the Cap** The menu gives you a little history about this family owned establishment. Generous on the portions, this is the dream for every hungry person on the prowl for some good old American comfort food. I could remember places like this always putting a smile on my face when I was a young boy. Glad to see Chicago is still holding it down. CHI TOWN FAVORITE!Talk about hitting the spot, this place is your dream come true. Low key with no wait for seating, we quickly ordered about half the menu without a second thought.In food measurement units - I think we ordered a boat load. The apps here are the perfect bite if your looking for a tapas style lunch (small plates). Great for sharing and trying a bunch of things while sipping on a cold brew. Our stomachs were growling since we had all skipped breakfast and clearly we went in hot and heavy. Take no prisoners!!! Round 1Slow cooked jumbo chicken wings, crispy and delicious.Smother everything in blue cheese is what I always say!Guinness braised,  Hormone free pulled pork with creamy Italian style polenta. A taste of the transitional and the new world. I could eat this everyday for a month.Big plate of Blackie's style poutine, which are like disco fair style hand cut fries. They had me at cheese & truffle oil, but the fried egg on top made my day. It's a foodie fact, everything is better with a sunny side fried egg on top. Break into the center and watch the liquid gold drizzle over the crispy french fries. My eyes teared up in pure joy after the first bite.We washed down our first round with a seasonal local brew.Clearly a local favorite from the recommendation, but did I mention all the apps were cheap, nothing was over $7. Round 2They make it very difficult to pick a sandwich with all the tasty menu options, but I went with what seamed like the most obvious choice - The Blackie's burger, which was fully loaded with melty cheese, smoked bacon, caramelized onions, mushrooms and organic greens. I personally love organic produce, which is always hard to find when your eating out and on a budget. All this was stacked on top of a hot juicy fresh Black Angus patty. The golden brioche bun was the perfect delivery system to grip my hands around. I could not have dreamed up a more yummy hamburger.WARNING: You will need another drink to wash it down, and it is very easy to get carried away when pitchers of beer are only $5. CHEAP COLD BEER ! ! !This good ol' American spot is a local Chicago gem. If you are passing through The South Loop area or looking for a new place to try, then stop by Blackie's. You will not be disappointed. The menu selections are all mouthwatering and the bang for your buck is through the roof.

10.description: The fact that the owner decided to tell me "goodluck in your life, you don't seem like a happy person" just because I thought their food was not great goes to show the professionalism. I'm sorry I did not like your food but I think you have no right to comment on my life because of it. Have a great day.If I could give you negative stars I would, it seems like the most terrible thing about this place is the nasty/witty comments the owner makes to people who leave less than perfect reviews. Take the criticism and improve upon it. Don't bash your customers on yelp and twitter.

5.description: I like going here for cheap pitchers of beer and decent fries.  The bar is weirdly dark but the patio is nice and I like that they let dogs on the patio, that's pretty great.Blackies kind of seems like a place that's trying to do fancy, gastropub food, but should really just stick to the basics. I have tried the pork sliders, the French burger, the poutine a la blackies, and the truffle mac n cheese (been here a few times, lol). -the poutine: truffle fries are good but these are just outrageously soggy and the egg doesn't do much other than conflict with the truffle flavor.  I love, love truffle flavor and the idea is good and the flavors are decent, just not well-executed.-the truffle mac n cheese - on a truffle vein...this is so bland!!!  It's not cheesy or creamy, it's just very plain and faint tasting.  -pork sliders - SO GOOD.  I got a few of these to share and subsequently refused to share.  They were just delicious, rich with flavor, and juicy.  Not too complicated, just right.-French burger - the patty itself was good, and nicely cooked, but despite the myriad of ingredients, the burger itself was unremarkable in terms of taste.In terms of atmosphere: the patio is lovely and I don't necessarily mind the inside, but why is it so dark?  It makes blackies seem...dirty, and I feel like that's (hopefully) not the case. Also, the decor inside is so fun and you can hardly see it!Service: to be honest, the service is never great here.  The servers and bar staff are very cold and often take a while with checks or checking on you.  I don't mind that much but it's not a great impression!  I also don't understand the rudeness of the comments that the owner makes on people's reviews.  If I hadn't seen those, I'd probably keep going to blackies - its location is nice and the beer is cheap.  However, the response from the owner to a lot of these people leaves a pretty sour taste in my mouth, despite the good taste of the food and I don't know if I want to support a business owner that does that...having worked in the restaurant industry for most of my life, he doesn't seem like someone I'd want to work for.  PS I'm sure I will also get a rude response for this commentary?  I try to keep my reviews pretty unbiased.  I like Blackies but it's definitely got room to improve!  Further, to address things you may say/ seem to say a lot, Jeff T, I can assure you that 1. I have never worked at your establishment and 2. I am definitely not too "high brow"

3.description: Solid spot on Printer's Row.  The prices were surprisingly inexpensive, the food was good if not amazing, and the service was excellent.  Definitely recommend.

35.description: Great burger. I liked the J. Lohr red wine. Good service. Beer list isn't bad either. They have quite a few craft beers. I'd come back.

19.description: Good burger. Horribly unfriendly service. He was a Mexican waiter I don't know if it was because he didn't speak much English or something, but I've had friendlier service at steak n' shake at 2am. The guy never checked in on us, the bus boy had to get us our 2nd round of drinks, not even sure if that's legal. I just didn't get it, how someone could be that unprofessional. Then we had to flag down another lady to have him bring us the bill, even though he was in eyesight drinking a coke behind the bar. I could understand if it was busy, but this guy just seemed lazy or didn't care at all. I won't return.

28.description: Great spot for lunch. Since it's located a couple blocks from my office, I come here at least a couple times a month and am never disappointed when leaving. Food is excellent and prices are rather affordable.Plus, you can't go wrong with supporting a local, family-owned small business.

45.description: Had salmon burger for lunch, and the whole meal, including fries, was really tasty. Loved the draft IPA from Colorado! A little-known feature are several private rooms, including a speakeasy downstairs. These would be great for events!

33.description: Blackie's was fine. It is a neighborhood bar that's been around for a long time. Since it is right by my daughter's apartment, we met there.It's got that neighborhood bar feel. I have to agree with some of the comments made here about service. It was 6ish on a Saturday evening, and they were not crowded at all. There were, perhaps, four tables with people at them and one person sitting at the bar. Getting the server's attention should have been easy, but no.The food was actually pretty good. I had their fully loaded burger - it came out well done when I'd ordered medium. But, the meat was well seasoned and juicy, so the fact that it was overcooked was not so noticeable. It comes with pickles, sauteed onions, mixed green lettuce and tomato. I skipped the cheese. The fries were fresh, hand cut and were very good.I've wanted to try Blackies for a while, and it was a fair experience. With all of the new options popping up in the gentrifying South Loop, they may have to start to work on their service to survive.Oh, make sure you stop into their restrooms. While they are small/cramped, they have interesting posters on the walls and ceilings. I understand that they have similar posters in the ladies restroom too, but they cater to the sexes.

43.description: Stopped here for lunch.A nice day so we sat outside and enjoyed the weather.Had one of their burgers and it was good. Not the best I ever had but still enjoyable. If you're in the neighborhood , not a bad spot to stop for a sandwich and a drink.Cheers to all

2.description: this didnt need to impress me just satisfy me - and it BARELY did that.first of all - a bloody marry is NOT bloody mix and absolute vodka - you MUST at least give me a pickle - some olivers but do yourselves a favor and get some salami - cheese - its cheap and people will be impressed... NOT disappointed.the wings had NO sauce - they were decent but get yourselves some hot sauce.  the classic burger was cooked decent - but the muschrooms were hard and the tomatoe slices way too thick.just get your bar food in order and you'll have a bunch of better reviews.

18.description: Old School Chicago bar!Really liked the place, going back to see the Hawks play!Enjoyed their French Burger, delicious!

41.description: Casual Americana Pub Style Fare at it's finest!Came into Blackie's South Loop on the recommendation of a local. **Tip of the Cap** The menu gives you a little history about this family owned establishment. Generous on the portions, this is the dream for every hungry person on the prowl for some good old American comfort food. I could remember places like this always putting a smile on my face when I was a young boy. Glad to see Chicago is still holding it down. CHI TOWN FAVORITE!Talk about hitting the spot, this place is your dream come true. Low key with no wait for seating, we quickly ordered about half the menu without a second thought.In food measurement units - I think we ordered a boat load. The apps here are the perfect bite if your looking for a tapas style lunch (small plates). Great for sharing and trying a bunch of things while sipping on a cold brew. Our stomachs were growling since we had all skipped breakfast and clearly we went in hot and heavy. Take no prisoners!!! Round 1Slow cooked jumbo chicken wings, crispy and delicious.Smother everything in blue cheese is what I always say!Guinness braised,  Hormone free pulled pork with creamy Italian style polenta. A taste of the transitional and the new world. I could eat this everyday for a month.Big plate of Blackie's style poutine, which are like disco fair style hand cut fries. They had me at cheese & truffle oil, but the fried egg on top made my day. It's a foodie fact, everything is better with a sunny side fried egg on top. Break into the center and watch the liquid gold drizzle over the crispy french fries. My eyes teared up in pure joy after the first bite.We washed down our first round with a seasonal local brew.Clearly a local favorite from the recommendation, but did I mention all the apps were cheap, nothing was over $7. Round 2They make it very difficult to pick a sandwich with all the tasty menu options, but I went with what seamed like the most obvious choice - The Blackie's burger, which was fully loaded with melty cheese, smoked bacon, caramelized onions, mushrooms and organic greens. I personally love organic produce, which is always hard to find when your eating out and on a budget. All this was stacked on top of a hot juicy fresh Black Angus patty. The golden brioche bun was the perfect delivery system to grip my hands around. I could not have dreamed up a more yummy hamburger.WARNING: You will need another drink to wash it down, and it is very easy to get carried away when pitchers of beer are only $5. CHEAP COLD BEER ! ! !This good ol' American spot is a local Chicago gem. If you are passing through The South Loop area or looking for a new place to try, then stop by Blackie's. You will not be disappointed. The menu selections are all mouthwatering and the bang for your buck is through the roof.

52.description: I had to renew my yelp account in order to write a review for Blackies South Loop. Amazing staff and management, the food is high quality and most definitely delicious. I live near Blackies and frequently stop in whether it be for some drinks or drinks and food. Best burgers around! If you're in printers row, you need to stop in and enjoy! I know I do!

50.description: I've been to Blackie's a couple of times now. First, the food:  it's simple American fare, and so far everything I've had has been fresh, well prepared, and delicious.  The price is very reasonable and the portions are substantial. The service was also decent, with attentive staff and a nice demeanor. Decor?  Well there I give it a C. It is definitely clean but it does suffer a bit from the cheap 1990-vintage decor, maybe slightly influenced by Miami Vice.So!  Four stars, basically minus one for the physical space.

4.description: Blackie's was fine. It is a neighborhood bar that's been around for a long time. Since it is right by my daughter's apartment, we met there.It's got that neighborhood bar feel. I have to agree with some of the comments made here about service. It was 6ish on a Saturday evening, and they were not crowded at all. There were, perhaps, four tables with people at them and one person sitting at the bar. Getting the server's attention should have been easy, but no.The food was actually pretty good. I had their fully loaded burger - it came out well done when I'd ordered medium. But, the meat was well seasoned and juicy, so the fact that it was overcooked was not so noticeable. It comes with pickles, sauteed onions, mixed green lettuce and tomato. I skipped the cheese. The fries were fresh, hand cut and were very good.I've wanted to try Blackies for a while, and it was a fair experience. With all of the new options popping up in the gentrifying South Loop, they may have to start to work on their service to survive.Oh, make sure you stop into their restrooms. While they are small/cramped, they have interesting posters on the walls and ceilings. I understand that they have similar posters in the ladies restroom too, but they cater to the sexes.

6.description: So I used to come to blackies ever since I moved to the hood back in the day, years ago. The food was always good enough and the drinks were always cheap enough. They got a new chef in the last couple years and the food was still good. But...Awhile back I was planning a dinner event for big group and I wanted to have it in the side dining room space at Blackies; I liked the spot and wanted to keep in the hood. So reached out and called. The guy wasn't in, I said I lived in the hood and they said just stop by later to talk to the guy. I did. Wife and I stopped in. When we sat down and ordered a drink and asked to speak to the guy. Never comes out. We were hungry so decided to get some dinner while waiting, we ask again, after dinner we ask again. Dude never came out. Lastly we were told there was a call off in the kitchen and he was too busy to speak with us - after we have been sitting there for a long long time. Look.. There were 6 other patrons in the whole place. Perhaps 2 of them were eating. Not even a courtesy handshake and a card if too busy? Really? I felt pretty disrespected when I'm trying to bring a large dinner function in. Best part was, on Polk you can see into the kitchen, when we left we saw homeboy standing there.. Really? I can see you man ha ha.. Needless to say, our big dinner wasn't held here and I can't come back in good conscious after that. I'd especially caution anybody trying to plan an event here. In fairness, I'm sure the food is still decent and the drinks are still cheap.

22.description: Not impressed.Ordered dinner from Blackie's last night for take out. We ordered the linguine and the tortellini. When we went to pick it up we were given a brown paper bag and we didn't check it until we got home... At which point we realized they gave us 2 Caesar salads. We called back and they said they realized they gave us the wrong order when the other people came to get their salads... Well thanks a lot for the call... It would have been nice to know before we got all the way home. So we kept the salads and went back to pick up our pasta and were shocked to see that these $12 pasta dishes were TINY... Like the boxes it came in we thought were for bread. What a joke!!! The food was actually pretty good but absolutely ridiculously priced for the portion we got. Get real Blackie's... You're a bar, not a gourmet restaurant.... Either lower your prices or up your portions because it's absurd. No apology received, ridiculous pricing, average food. Safe to say I won't go back.

15.description: Blackie's is a bar. An old bar. No more than a bar. An "old-fashioned bar. A traditional bar, with traditional drinks and traditional bar style, stick to your ribs food. While the menu has been updated to include several more chic food items, there's always the cheeseburger and waffle fries that has been a staple for decades. It's been in Printer's Row for what seems like forever; long before I was born. My mom's Bachelorette Party with the stereotypically annoying stripper was at none other than Blackie's, in the mid 1980's. Blackie's is so chock full of nostalgia and fun memories for my family. My mom lived in the neighborhood after college and Blackie's was one of my parents' favorite haunts when they were dating and wanted a bar away from Rush Street. Funny thing is, I like Blackie's now as much as my parents liked Blackie's in the 1980's. The salmon burger was pretty fantastic, as were the waffle fries. Really fresh, crunchy yet savory and flavorful. The portion of both is so ample, there was more than enough to gorge and have enough to take home for later or the next day. Bread is fresh and tasty, fish is moist and delicious, fries are just plain wonderful. Blackie's is one of the few places that remains fabulous and consistent and open for business. I hope they're around for the next several decades. The way they do A Bar, I think they will be!!

57.description: Blackie's went out of their way to correct an incident I had with them. A business that corrects their mistakes is one that will last. I really appreciate their gesture and am excited to come in and try some of these new menu items and daily specials.

20.description: Old School Chicago bar!Really liked the place, going back to see the Hawks play!Enjoyed their French Burger, delicious!

36.description: My husband and I decided to get lunch in Chicago.  This is our first trip to Blackie's. The bartender greeted us as soon as we walked in.  A very friendly waitress was at our table within a couple of minutes. I got the Reuben, which is one of my favorite sandwiches.  It's delicious. The best Reuben I can ever remember eating. To top it off, now my favorite Frank Sinatra song "That's Life" is playing. This is a good place.

14.description: Burger is awesome Great outdoor spot as well Lots of options Great spot I'll be back 5 stars

58.description: Great selection of wine, with some very reasonably priced specials.  Limited but very interesting selection of beer.  Individual chilled bottles of beer start at $5.  Funky neighborhood.

56.description: Such a cute little place with a fantastic selection of wine, beer and spirits.  The staff is knowledgeable and laid back and will steer you in the right direction if asked.Though I popped in here for libations for my gentleman caller and I, the extra star is for being whistled at on the way out.  I knew I was rocking that red dress!

29.description: Love this place.  The staff is so friendly, and they have a great selection.  Be on the look out if you can get a groupon, it's a solid deal.

42.description: We had us a good ole time at Printer's Row Wine Shop during Lit Fest this weekend. All I have to say is, I have never been to a wine shop that is more fun than a bar! They will let you drink whatever you buy, right there. Anyway, we stopped in just to look around and wound up staying and drinking for two hours. Lots of cool locals to chat with and the selection of wine, beer and alcohol is smart and eclectic. I was familiar with most of the offerings already but it was fun to see it all collected in one place. The shop itself is attractive, with high ceilings and hardwood floors. The owners are personable and laid back and cultivate a laid-back atmosphere. Unfortunately, they are Sox fans (j/k!- no, seriously)...The only negative to point out is that the prices skew $2-$5 more here than at other places where I buy wine and beer. Anyway, it's a great neighborhood stop and I will definitely be back. (Shout out to our friends, Gilles and Hal!)

23.description: Let me put it like this:  I like Printer's Row Wine Shop so much that, even though I live in the northern part of Streeterville, this is my preferred shop for all things Bacchus.  Period.  If I'm in the neighborhood, I have to stop in just to poke around.  Is it the awesome people who work there?  The great selection?  The down-to-earth atmosphere?  I have no clue.  There always seems to be something interesting to try, regardless of your mood: Fun craft beers, fantastic wines, wonderful spirits (including awesome bourbon)!  If cost is your concern, Printer's Row Wine Shop is competitive with most, and even if you have to spend an extra dollar, you get more value from your visit than you do from a Big Box Booze store.  No glazed over zombies in matching polos here.  It's a educated person's Drinking shop, and class is always in session... leave your pretentiousness at the door.

47.description: This is a great little wine shop in Printer's Row.  My boyfriend and I come here regularly since we live close by.  Actually, we stumbled upon this place by accident after a horrendous experience at the nearby Warehouse Liquors (read my review on it for more on that).The owner is quite friendly and helpful.  They have a great selection of different wines in a wide array of prices.  The prices reflect the neighborhood, so you could definitely find cheaper altneratives, but not in the area.  The atmosphere of the shop is very clean and rustic.  Their craft beer selection is wonderful!  We've tried all kinds of different seasonal beers from this shop over the last year.  They have a small selection of spirits, which is fine.  They have all the basics covered and a few unique options here and there, but the real reason to come here is for the beer and/or wine.I love it!

8.description: It's kind of dumb, actually, to review places like liquor stores. No matter what, people WILL patronize a liquor store if they want/need their fix. But then there are people like me who actually prefer to spend my hard-earned dollars & support businesses that actually appreciate and respect their customers. I realized after a certain amount of time that I didn't get this here. Have spent way too much money over the years & put up with way too much attitude and/or indifference in this hypermasculine establishment. Part of the whole point of supporting a neighborhood business is that there's supposed to be a familiarity, a congeniality, a level of respect that you're not necessarily going to get at a big box where you know they don't know you. Well, if you're not getting that then it's best to go elsewhere. And the beauty of liquor stores & even speciality wine shops is that there is always another one. Especially in Chicago, thank goodness, there is always another one...

31.description: LOVE This place.Rob and Flavio take FANTASTIC care of their regulars.  The prices are a little high on some items, but totally worth it because they treat you like a human being and appreciate your business.Always a killer beer selection.They also recently got turn tables installed.  FUN!

34.description: Perfect local wine and beer shop - knowledgeable owners/staff, unique high-end beer, and a pretty decent wine selection.  They beefed up their beer list not too long ago - and it's quite extensive now.  I'm not much into beer (but will not say no to a yummy glass of red wine), but it's fun to try some of their offerings as they really are unique and tasty.  Oh, and they have a wine tasting every Friday evening - so taste before you buy!

16.description: I'm a sucker for craft beer. I love trying new brews but hate when I can never find them again. Enter Printers Row Wine Shop.I went in for Pumking today (after googling where i could get it nearby) but was thrilled to have found New Holland brews, Founders, other Southern Tier, etc. I left with a much higher total but I had planned but my new bag helped with that!What bag you ask? $2 for a bag that holds 4 beers in place and gave me 10% off my purchase today and will continue to do so forever and ever. Aside from the products- the dude working was also really pleasant. He asked only once if I needed anything (more would have annoyed me) and didn't stare while I meandered around. We had a nice chat before I left as well. Cool guy. Long story short, I became a loyal customer in the matter of minutes. Great selection, nice people, good deals, awesome vibe.

13.description: Love this little shop! The owners are so knowledgeable and every bottle is chosen for a reason to be there. You can find anything good in any price range (even beer), and I dearly miss their Friday night tastings. J'adore!

11.description: I went in this morning to find a few local beers to bring back home for my husband and the guy who assisted me was super friendly and helpful. Great selection! Wine selection was great too!

39.description: I shopped here for the first time with a 50% off Groupon, and I couldn't have been more impressed with the service, selection and ambiance of the place.  The man working was knowledgeable and helpful, even though he knew that I had a Groupon and probably couldn't afford to spend a lot of money.  He asked me what type of beers I liked, and then helped me find new bottles that I would enjoy based on my tastes.  Boy was he right.  Definitely going back -- maybe next time to try the wine.  Or the liquor...

37.description: I challenge you to imagine what a wine/beer shop in the heart of Printer's Row looking like, then step in here and tell me it is not exactly what you pictured. There are bottles of wine stacked against every spot of wall, there are old barrels filled with goodies, tables featuring some deals, coolers and racks filled with fancy beer, liquor bottles stacked behind the long counter, homemade greeting cards to go along with the gift you are picking up, and even some gourmet-ish snacks to go along with whatever beverage you purchase. I should share that I am not what you would call a "boozer", in fact I know almost nothing about wine and beer. However, I am engaged to a man that could write a book on beer and I can safely say that the guy that is always working here (possibly the owner?) always has a chat with him about what's new, how to concoct your own mix of beer, and their favorites from around the world. The prices here vary, I don't think this is where you go to buy cheap stuff but there are certainly plenty of options on the more cost-effective side, as well as some options to splurge on. I definitely encourage you to come here for their expertise and selection, and please give them your money instead of the grocery and convenient stores around the area.

0.description: This place is an example of the style of Printers Row. This quaint little shop has original hardwood floors and a careful organization of every bottle of wine, or beer.They also sell cheeses, meats, crackers and treats! They will assist you if you get confused all you need to do is stand there long enough to be offered help! Customer service here is A-1.If you go to this place I'm sure you will find something that you never tried to enjoy.... So go ahead and enjoy!

38.description: These guys are very friendly and helpful!  Would come here again anytime!

51.description: This is one of my favorite neighborhood haunts. The staff is super helpful and they have a wide variety of wines (yes they've got some fabulous $10 specials) and treats. I was pleasantly surprised when I went to buy two bottles as hostess gifts and they actually "wrapped" them. Nothing fancy but they'll put a stamp with the name of the store and tie them up with some twine. Definitely a nice touch and from a classy Printer's Row wine joint what more can you ask for?

27.description: My absolute favorite place to buy wine.  Note, they have a great selection of quality liquor as well.The atmosphere just oozes cool.  With old hardwood floors and wood shelving, the place feels as if it was plucked straight out of the early 20th century.  The recent addition of turn tables and the guys playing real vinyl and you just want to hang out for extended periods of time.Service is awesome.  You don't get the typical 'I know so much about wine, let me tell you about it and why you don't ' attitude.  The guys are always ready to make some suggestion, but honestly, I typically go with whatever they have on special in the front of the shop.  I like trying new wines and really trust them to put out some good choices.You can put your flashers on and pop in, which makes parking easy.

32.description: Stopped in this shop to find a relatively small shop with somewhat bare shelves. I knew the answer to this though, its the groupon effect (a rush of consumers in the final deal days buying up what is available) and I was contributing with my expiring voucher. I didn't have trouble finding a few bottles that sounded good though. I found the clerk nice, not too much interaction though. I'm not sure I'd go out of my way to this shop. I find security in thinking I'm getting a fairer price at a larger store rather than a small local shop surviving in the big city, especially when it comes to wine (not a forte of mine).

54.description: This Wine and Beer shop is amazing! my boyfriend and i just happened to stumble in one night after going to Villians and we've been back every week for something every since.Since i dont know too much about beer, i really appreciate the staff taking the time to suggest bottles and types for me that i would have never picked up otherwise. They suggested the best $3 hefeweizen that i will ever drink in my life and i've always picked up a bottle when i'm there now. They also have a great arrangement of off the wall beers, such as Banana Bread (which is yummy!)If you are in the South Loop and have a moment just to browse they always have a great wine selection and dont mind answering any questions. Another thing i really appreciate was that the clerks didn't pretend to know things. I wanted to know about a certain beer and they jumped on the computer and told me everything they could find out it. It was great!

48.description: Helpful staff, great (free) wine tastings on Fridays, unique selection of wine (and beer)!  Nothing I hate more than going to a boutique wine shop and seeing grocery store brands line the walls.My only complaint is that the markup seems a little high...but it's a small business.  I understand.

44.description: I lived in Printer's Row for a year, and this little wine shop is still one of my favorite places to buy wine.  The have a decent selection and prices for being in the loop area.  On multiple occasions, they would be sampling wine when I would go in- which is always a plus ;) And the employees were always super friendly and helpful!

24.description: Very knowledgeable staff who know wine from different regions very well!

7.description: Is this a...dare I say it...hidden gem?  Ugh, I can't believe I just typed that.  My college professors would probably weep at the fact that I couldn't come up with something more original.  Seriously though, I want to know how a store has [beer name withheld] sitting right there on the counter a week after it pops up in all the beer stores.  This place HAS to be a hidden gem.Oh wait, it's a wine shop.  They just happen to have a small yet splendid selection of craft beers.  I can dig it.  Called to see if they had a few beers.  They even set aside said beers, even though it would be a few hours before I'd be in.  I hate when the place down the street from where I work won't even hold a damn beer that's not all that popular (but down to their last one that hasn't moved in days), yet this place had no qualms about holding their last 2 bottles of something that some beer nerd easily could have come in looking for.  After a little chatting and a little buying, I asked myself "self, what can you get the woman who birthed you and currently has everything thanks to you and your step-dad for her birthday?"  I answered myself with "wine", because what mom who drinks one margarita and asks for "another margaritee please" WOULNDN'T want booze?  (In case you missed that, my mom isn't a drinker.  Who gets drunk off one margarita?  Pfft.)  I'm so thoughtful.  I really liked that despite spending more than I should have on booze (including an impulse buy, thanks to it being on the counter and all), when I asked for help picking a wine and said "no more than $50 please" I wasn't met with nothing but $50 wines.  In fact, I picked two wines that were roughly $20-$22.  I don't know my wine like I know my beer, but I was able to help him narrow it down to a few bottles for me to choose from.  I spoke with one gentleman on the phone and was helped by a different one upon arrival, but both were very pleasant to deal with.  I like that in a wine shop.  I also like that I was signed up for their rewards program.  Looks like I'll have to find a way to work this CBHG into my rotation.

49.description: Without a doubt the best liquor store in the city.The staff is super friendly, and they are the only retailer (as well as sister-store Gentile's on the campus of UIC) to carry Vinejoy products.Vinejoy has an amazing selection of wine and other liquors and I truly believe that they are on the rise in the competitive Chicago market for high-quality wine.I love the decor, the overall feel, and selection that Printers Row has and you can always hear great music being played while in-store.The Loop is a convenient location no matter what way you are getting there on the CTA, so there really is no reason other than perhaps laze to make a trip down to Printers Row.YOU WILL NOT BE DISAPPOINTED! Definitely inquire about Vinejoy for some top-notch wine.

40.description: After Sam's closed down in 2009, this is where I went for all my craft beers.  Good selection and cool guys running the place.  Their prices are a bit high compared to Binny's, but it's a small business, so it's understandable.  I didn't buy much wine there, but they seem to have good choices at various prices, as well as hard liqour and cigars.All in all, it's a good place if you live in the area, but to be honest, had Sam's not closed, I probably wouldn't ever go here.

53.description: love this place. i always stop when i'm in the neighborhood. they have great prices and can suggest a great wine or two for any dish!

30.description: Nice little neighborhood wine and beer shop. I'm not so familiar with their wine selection, but the beer selection is really nice, they always have an array of craft brews. The prices are pretty good, sometimes significantly less than the more well-known liquor stores. The staff is always friendly, too.

46.description: Visit on a Friday night and request a TV sitcom theme song and they'll play it! Great vibe, sick selection. Col times.

1.description: If this were my neighborhood wine, beer, and liquor store, I'd definitely be a happy camper.Their selection is top notch, and there's always someone knowledgable there willing to help. I was particularly impressed by their sake and local beer selection.Don't forget the loyalty points! If you come here enough, leave your name and score major discounts. Or, don't hesitate to leave my name.

55.description: Printer's Row Wine Shop is awesome if you are into inebriation, which, fortunately for them, I am. I don't know much about wine, but it looks like they do in fact have all two colors of it, so that is a plus.Looking beyond the obvious best feature of being only a couple blocks from home, their beer selection is also awesome and the staff is always nice and helpful. A few blocks away from the heart of downtown Chicago, it is good to know a place that feels like a small local neighborhood shop. They constantly rotate in their craft beer section and the staff is pretty knowledgable about recommendations and what is good seasonally. They also always stock a variety of sample packs from random breweries around the country, so it is fun to try something new and learn by trying new things. When my girlfriend and I got obsessed with pumpkin ale during last October (or ROCKtober, if that's your preference), their employee Nate put some behind the counter for us for a while without us asking, assuming we were coming in eventually. $35 extra YelpBucks for that.They carry the crappy stuff too, but don't walk too far down the beer aisle and be that dickhead that goes into a nice unique shop and buys a case of miller lite. I wish they would price 30 packs of college-beer at like $100 a case just to get across "you're a douchebag."

9.description: What a great shop. This is definitely my go to in the neighborhood any time I need wine, beer, or spirits. I moved into Printer's Row just over a year ago and am so glad I found this place. The weekly wine tastings are always good, but I really enjoy the periodic spirit tastings they have. The staff is very friendly and knowledgeable.On a side note, I love that the shop offers rewards points on purchases. I've never heard of another wine shop that does this.

26.description: This place reminds me of all stop shop of wine, beer, spirits, with few cigars in Williamsburg (Brooklyn) without the hipsters. Of course in NYC, this doesn't exist.As you enter, the music playing is not coming from an iPod, but vinyl records on turntables. The store is small, but clean and neatly organized.One of the workers came by and asked if we needed help. I politely declined, as I drooled over the selection of craft beer bottles in the fridge. Some wines have nice descriptions of flavor profiles on placards, so I wish all of them did.Overall, Printers Row Wine Shop is an impressive wine and spirits shop and open late (11pm).Watch your step on the way out! I forgot I had to step up to get in and almost tucked and rolled on the way out.IFHTP 1

25.description: I feel so lucky to have this unique wine shop in my hood!While not as big as the super-store-wine-shops, Printers Row Wine Shop has a rustic elegance that allows you to peruse wines from every region imaginable.  If you are a fan of European reds (and c'mon, who's not?) then you'll find a fantastic selection.Best yet--Printers Row Wine shop has tastings of 5 or so wines, which is fun to indulge in.  They also have sales on a variety of wines, and a wine of the month club.Mostly though, it's just a relaxing atmosphere--not pretentious at all.  Wine snobs need not enter!  Thanks Printers Row Wine Shop for being such a great part of the neighborhood.

12.description: Environment: 5/5Employees: 3/5Cost: 3/5Parking: 4/5Total: 15/20Synopsis: When I first arrived in Chicago, I knew I needed to find something like Hasr, to meet people, drink wine, have special treatment. However, by comparison this place fell lower than expected. Customer service is not robust, but the fact that it has to be a "suitable" replacement would have to suffice.Environment: Quite an elegant place and very organized! Wooden floors that look sharp, sturdy, and releases and Earthy essence. Homely like. 5/5Employees: Have mostly an average experience or poor service. Makes my eyes roll after being engaged. However, the knowledge of the people are exquisite and they know their stuff! They even are good at offering recommendations.Cost: It depends on what you get and what deals are available. I would not say, "Come here for the price."Parking: For where it is, parking is plentiful. They even have a huge section for parking just require moolah to pay.

59.description: Quaint wine shop that sells everything else you might need for a night alone in front of the TV with just you and the bottle...Okay, all kidding aside; it's a nice place.  The sales associates know what they're talking about and don't try to force the most expensive wine on you.  There are cheeses, chilled wines, hard liquor, some mixers, cigars, and alcohol flavored chocolate to accompany the wines on the shelf.  All in all, go go go to the Printer's Row Wine Shop!

21.description: These guys were awesome!  As a wine novice, I wanted to buy a boss's gift and they nailed it.  Were incredibly helpful and steered me to an outstanding selection as it turned out.

17.description: Mon dieu. I've since sampled all of the three wines I bought that day. Aforementioned Fiction was fantastic, as was the anti Red.But the one that made me moist was the Agua de Piedra (Foot water?!) Malbec. Whoa. This is a wine that will make your panties dissolve. Dry, dry, DRY, and bold, baby.I will so make the trek back to Printers Row for more of that goodness. Mmmmmm.

10.description: Are you one of those people who will buy a beer/cider/wine/booze based on the label or packaging? Do you like to browse and read patter on the labels? Do you think finding a good bottle of alcohol is like a treasure hunt?I do, and I LOVE this place. I'm fairly sure that the employees think I'm lost or going to steal something because I spend so long just browsing the ever-so-slightly-changing selection, reading the labels, and then buying based on cool name or awesome patter. I've had some hits, a LOT of misses, but that's not the point. The fun is in the hunt. On the less exotic side, I have found tall boys of Magners and Strongbow here, and for that, they are forever in my heart. Sure, there are cheaper places, but the service and the selection here makes up for any cost differential. But I think I need more tats to fit in. Oh well. We can't all be winners.

5.description: I needed to buy a bottle of champagne for my brother in law and didn't have time to go to a big store on the way home. A quick search on Yelp led to me this great little shop. If you're thinking this is a great alternative to Binny's, it's not. It doesn't have the same selection nor size. But what it lacks in space, it makes up for in weekly wine tastings, beer tastings, customer service and honest to goodness passion in the product.

3.description: Worst wine store I ever encountered in Chicago-land or anywhere else for that matter. Poor selection, semi-bare shelves, disinterested staff, no gratis gift wrapping available from what I was told. The semi-comatose clerk acted like he was doing me a favor when he snipped the price off a bottle I intended as a gift. Then he slid it into a plain brown paper bag. Class act. I'm sure glad this isn't my neighborhood liquor store. This was my first time here, essentially my welcome to the neighborhood, and I won't be back (if I can help it). I'm off to Binny's right now and hopefully their awesome selection, good service and loyalty program will erase some of the bad taste I got from this establishment.

35.description: Hidden gem of a nicely done smaller and selective wine shop in the south streets of Printer's row.   Mr. and Mrs. Groupon led me here but I had jogged by a few times before and wanted to come back. Very nice helpful suggestions and great deals of wines that turned out to be quite good.  Need to come back for my local wine needs.  Nice diversity of prices and types.

19.description: This place is seriously one of the best wine shops I've ever been to. I have never had a bottle of wine from there that I did not like. The staff are some of the better-educated I've ever encountered, and since they're not dealing with such a massive selection, they tend to know a lot about each bottle they carry.  Bottom line, get your wine here.

28.description: Great selection of wine and beers.  They have a lot of great micro-brews from around the country and local breweries.  The store also has a nice selection of cigars and other tobacco products for those who are inclined.  Staff is very friendly and prices are fair.

45.description: I always enjoyed coming in here when my sister lived in Printer's Row.  It was so convenient, and has a great selection of wine!  Everyone working is always friendly and helpful.

33.description: This is such a cute little wine shop with a pretty extensive selection.  I stopped in for the first time today because I had purchased a Groupon that was about to expire.  As far as prices go, they seemed pretty competitive.  I like that they had a lot of wines from places I recently visited in Napa.  I just wish I discovered this spot when I actually lived in the neighborhood!

43.description: Absolutely amazing selection of micro brews and wines.  I also really dig the feel of the store.  Very printers row.  lolz.  They also ahve beer and wine tastings quite regularly (join the email mailing list).  Very Nice

2.description: This shop is super cool. Their selection is stellar. They carry really rare stuff and their staff is knowledgeable. Whats the problem? The price. I bought a batch of four roses - small batch bourbon. I saw the price tag, $43, and asked the gentleman at the counter if this was a fair price as I thought this was overpriced but was unsure if I was getting it confused with single barrel. The hipster behind the counter told me "no, I've never seen it cheaper". What a D. Binny's sells this for $29.99. I do not care what these guys sell, I will not go back there. I will gladly drive an extra two miles to find this somewhere else. Fairly unhipster move IMO btw. That beard, skinny jeans, and beanie suggested some sort of hipster code that I thought guaranteed my liquor purchase to be a reasonable deal. False. If I was Wilford Brimley, I would name this store Diabetes, it's the worst.

18.description: Great selection of wine and beer. The owners are super friendly and extremely helpful. The shop has a fun neighborhood feel to it. Everyone who visits is treated like a long time friend and often treated to a wine tasting! This spot is a true neighborhood gem and assets to printer row.

41.description: Mon dieu. I've since sampled all of the three wines I bought that day. Aforementioned Fiction was fantastic, as was the anti Red.But the one that made me moist was the Agua de Piedra (Foot water?!) Malbec. Whoa. This is a wine that will make your panties dissolve. Dry, dry, DRY, and bold, baby.I will so make the trek back to Printers Row for more of that goodness. Mmmmmm.

52.description: I was here for the great beer selection - not as many beers as wines, but still a good selection of regional and beyond.

50.description: I am very surprised by the glowing reviews this establishment has received. Laid back is an excellent description...so much so don't count on getting any assistance. You would think being a small neighborhood liquor store would survive being so discourteous however, young naive  college kids insure they survive. The worst is the owner, can't be bothered to say hello or thank you--- ever. This might be acceptable if their prices were reasonable but they are easily 20% higher than most liquor stores -- high prices, terrible service = 1 star

4.description: Haven't been impressed with this shop for years now. Staff always seem too cool to be bothered. A friend of mine had a very negative experience there recently but I needed to pick up a quick bottle on the way home from dinner knowing that nothing would be open the next day (Thanksgiving). Bought a bottle of FEW bourbon. $70. Wha?!?!? Are you kidding me? Are you charging so much because it's imported? No, wait, it's from Evanston! Same bottle is currently $40 at Binny's and $45 at Whole Foods. Yes, this place is more expensive than Whole Foods! I do like to support the local businessman but will never go there again. Sure, charge a couple more bucks, that's fine. But $30?!?! Warehouse Liquors is only a short walk away and, while they usually charge (a little) more than Binny's, the staff is awesome and actually appreciative of the business.

6.description: I stopped into this little shop last week when I was in town for a conference. Great selection of wines! Several of my favorites that are hard to fine were displayed on the shelves. They were having a free tasting which was also nice. Actual wine glasses for the tasting is a perk!The only odd thing was the staff interaction I had. There was only one guy working, and it was a little busy - maybe six people?  When checking out I mentioned I found the place on Yelp and the guy told me all about how much he hates this site! A little weird. Especially since I mentioned the site and they have great reviews.

22.description: A hipster-ed out alcohol sales joint. Parking is reasonable given Chicago standards. They carry a deep selection of wine for the space. Good micros. The staff seems to enjoy their job. A plus. They also have a wine tasting every Friday. Very interactive. A great place for a casual first date. There's a cool hamburger spot two doors down if things are clicking. But, if there's no connection at least you learn more about the art of wine. Overall, it's a win-win I tell ya!

15.description: My absolute favorite place to buy wine.  Note, they have a great selection of quality liquor as well.The atmosphere just oozes cool.  With old hardwood floors and wood shelving, the place feels as if it was plucked straight out of the early 20th century.  The recent addition of turn tables and the guys playing real vinyl and you just want to hang out for extended periods of time.Service is awesome.  You don't get the typical 'I know so much about wine, let me tell you about it and why you don't ' attitude.  The guys are always ready to make some suggestion, but honestly, I typically go with whatever they have on special in the front of the shop.  I like trying new wines and really trust them to put out some good choices.You can put your flashers on and pop in, which makes parking easy.

57.description: I fell in love with this shop. Fun wine selection and a great beer selection. They carry the sampler 12 pack of Great Lakes which I haven't seen anywhere recently. Good selection of Half Acre, they had the Ginger Twin, yay! Also the staff was great and told me about some beers that had just come in that weren't on display yet. This place is a godsend to get out of the craziness for a bit when at the book fair. Loaded up with books and all the beer I could ever want I left here for home totally satisfied.

20.description: This shop is a gem. I don't live in the south loop, but I will take the trek here to visit this wine shop. I'm not super cultered. I just like wine. This place understands that and works with that.First off, the service is impeccable. I came here on a whim on a Saturday night half an hour before closing, and I didn't feel like it was the end of the day type service. The guy who was working was really helpful and interesting and not in the least bit pretentious. He was also very conscious of our budget, which I appreciated. They have free wine tastings every Friday. I'm so glad I found this place.You're not going to buy a $3 bottle of Trader Joe's wine here, but why on earth would you want to? If you want $3 wine, go to Trader Joe's.

36.description: People often compare small neighborhood shops to mega marts and oversized beverage providers. And I have no idea why. To me, it's an unfair comparison for countless reasons. No small place can offer the limitless selection of a larger store while larger stores don't have the intimacy and service of a smaller place. That said, every neighborhood needs a shop like this. It's warm, inviting, and they have a great selection of beer and wine available.Is the store so great that I'd bypass my regular places to further my trip and head here? No. But I wish this place was in my building. I'll leave it at that.

14.description: This place reminds me of all stop shop of wine, beer, spirits, with few cigars in Williamsburg (Brooklyn) without the hipsters. Of course in NYC, this doesn't exist.As you enter, the music playing is not coming from an iPod, but vinyl records on turntables. The store is small, but clean and neatly organized.One of the workers came by and asked if we needed help. I politely declined, as I drooled over the selection of craft beer bottles in the fridge. Some wines have nice descriptions of flavor profiles on placards, so I wish all of them did.Overall, Printers Row Wine Shop is an impressive wine and spirits shop and open late (11pm).Watch your step on the way out! I forgot I had to step up to get in and almost tucked and rolled on the way out.IFHTP 1

3.description: Been here twice now. Selection is pretty good but pricey, but the staff is just too rude for it to be worth it. Rather just walk to 7-11 or CVS.

1.description: It's great for this area full of condos to have a quick stop pantry shop. It's not so great how friggin expensive everything is. A pack of Starburst for $1 and the cheapest gum I could find was $1.69, ugh.If you need something quick, it's great. You can run in & run out if you live right there. Or if you're passing by, you can easily park on the street with blinkers & run in. If you go to Target a block away, you have to deal with parking in their massive parking lot.No issues with service the few times I've been in. Guys aren't overly friendly but they definitely aren't rude in any way. The whole shop was well organized and clean every time I've gone in.

2.description: It's clean... It's convenient.... It's slightly over priced, but it is a convenience store, so it's expected. Honestly, their prices are cheaper than all of the other convenience stores in the area. *Shrugs* It's either Urban Pantry or a grocery store.

5.description: Wow! Another great addition to the South Loop.  This is right on Clark in Printer's Row Burnham Pointe Building. Super modern place that allows you to order groceries by text - if you wish.They have super friendly owners and you can find bread and pastries, vegetables and fruits.  They have coffee and wine. Option of online ordering with home delivery and curbside pick-up.

6.description: Forget quick convenience, this place always just leaves me annoyed and frustrated wishing I had walked the extra block to Target, 711 or any of the other convenient stores in the area.  The staff is extremely rude and always trying to get you to spend more money, I have been told there is a $3, $5 and $7 minimum to use credit, as well as no minimum at all... varies depending on the amount of my purchase.  One would think with the lack of business that they would take whatever customers they can get.

7.description: Simply put:  the previous two 1-star reviews are absurd.Reasons I LOVE this store:  1)  It's open until midnight every night except Sunday, when it closes at 10pm.  2)  It's immediately downstairs from my apt., and I don't even have to walk outside to get there (amazing in the winter).  3)  While they could overcharge ridiculously for the amazing convenience (see #2), they don't -- their prices are in line with Target (which is nearby).  4)  They have a pretty exotic beer selection.  It's not just your typical Coors, Miller, etc., but truly good beers.  Today, for example, I got a limited release "Lagunitas 'Little Sumpin' Wild'," which is epic.5) Their selection adapts over time.  When they first opened, they didn't have many home/bath products -- but they learned their business and their clientele and adapted.  Now, can often find that random something at the store without making the trip to Target.I feel genuinely sorry that a private business owner has to fear getting 1-star reviews because of one or two childishly unhappy customers, but that's just the modern age in which we live.Bottom Line:  This place is GREAT, and one of the perks of living in my building that makes me want to stay here for years to come!

8.description: I went to this store expecting to be blown away. The idea and concept is great but it's just poorly executed. It seems underfunded, disorganized and not real clean. Maybe they'll get their act together soon and I'll go back and give it a try.

0.description: If you are staying in the Financial District and looking for groceries this store is listed on Yelp as a grocery store which is incorrect.  It is a convenience store.  Grocery stores will have foods such as produce, milk, eggs etc.  stopped by earlier to learn of this mistake on the Yelp category.That being said it does have a nice selection of snack items at reasonable prices.  Craft and local brew selection is good, wine section was surprisingly nice and the service was friendly.  Useful convenience store indeed.

4.description: Fortunately, I've not experienced what the first two reviewers have noted.  I have some of my own notes:Location: 5 out of 5 (South Loop)If you happen to live in the south loop, it's actually quite convenient since it's in the ground floor of the Burnham Pointe apartments.  Parking is usually available on the street, though most of my "errands" here have all been on foot due to the super close proximity from my place.  As others have noted, it competes with Target and 7-Eleven from a geographical perspective.Service: 2.5 out of 5I wouldn't say the guys that work here are "rude" or "mean."  The guys that I presume are the proprietors are "nice enough" and they probably work stupid long hours so that their second generation Indian-subcontinent kids can have their own kids born into middle class like it ain't no thang.  The part time help guys are a little nicer, but still not what I would consider to be "happy."  I mean, they ask me if I want a bag for my beer, and they say, "thanks" as I walk out.  Good enough.Selection of Beer: 3 out of 5I've not perused the aisles (in the real meaning of the word, not the mistaken definition of 'browse') for foodstuffs or convenience items, but their beer selection will do in a pinch.  I'm actually pretty impressed by the amount of craft brewers they carry:  3 Floyds, 2 Bros, Bells, Flying Dog, Chimay, etc.  They've also got your typical run of the mill American style light lagers and well-established imports like Corona, Guiness, and Heineken.  I mean - could I walk another block to Printers Row Wine and find tons more beer?  Yes.  But if what I drink on a regular basis can be found here if I'm rushed for time, is there a need to do that?  No.Price of Beer: 2.5 out of 5Eh...noticeably more than other places where you might find craft beers.  Craft six packs are 1 - 2 dollars more expensive than anywhere else, and craft 12 packs are 2 - 3 dollars more.  I think once there was some mixup with the bar code, and I got a 6 pack of beer for 4.99 plus tax, which was awesome.  The next time I went, it was properly tagged at 8.99 or 9.99.  Boo.  Like I said - I come here if I'm pinched for time, and with that in mind, maybe the prices are worth it.  Cleanliness/Organization: 3 out of 5I don't recall seeing anything that was "dirty" or unorganized.  Things seemed to be running ok after they initially opened up in Q3 of 2011.  Overall: 3 out of 5 (beer centric)Close enough that I don't dismiss them if I'm in need of craft beer and I've forgotten to grab it on my weekly errands.  Expensive enough that it prevents me from coming here regularly.  I think for awhile they were trying to reach out to the college students by doing wine tastings and nominal discounts -maybe that will pick back up as more students get back after the summer is over.

58.description: Dined here twice. First time was beginner's luck and had a deal coupon, second time was also a deal coupon and affirmation not to return unless it's based on desperation. Disruptive noise from the bar, when sitting in the train car/dining section of the restaurant. Venue layout is a bizarre set up, to enter the dining area, you have to walk through the bar crowd which feels like a different establishment than the train car/dining section. The food is okay, it's filling due to its large portions but I've had much better Italian food. Waitstaff seems to be hardworking but not very knowledgeable about the menu.

56.description: Came here on a working lunch. FOOD: I wasn't footing the bill, but still ended up ordering only a $9.00 entree because everything else looked kind of heavy. I had the chicken asparagus salad, which was very good. A LOT of chicken, like the equivalent of two chicken breasts, which was nice. I took home an entire turkey breast. We also had the grilled calamari, which was delicious!SERVICE: The staff is fun and friendly. Food came fairly fast.AMBIANCE: Definitely feels like a real Italian place as opposed to an Olive Garden type feel. Kind of neat to be eating in an old train car. It seemed kind of dead at lunch time on a Friday, but maybe that's normal. I don't know.

29.description: Cute train car dining room. Friendly service and decent Italian food. Nice, old establishment in the South Loop.

42.description: Beautiful environment. The food was delicious and they even let us split the ravioli entree into two plates with the different sauces. The server was a bit of an old snappy Italian man with an attitude.

23.description: Cute dining car and bar here.  Food was OK lacked a bit of "finesse" for the prices for dinner I expect more. I'd imagine lunch and the bar here are really the way to go. Probably would not return for dinner just wasn't anything I'd come back for.

47.description: excellent food.  reasonably priced for Chicago.  Nice setting.  Visiting from out of town, and looked for several Italian restaurants.  Was not disappointed at all with this one.

8.description: This review is for the BAR area only.Totally great. This is one of those smallish "Grotto" type bars that look like they should be crawling with Playboy bunnies. Or lawyers. Or both. And it also looked like it hadn't been updated since the 70's. Yeah, now we are talking!I only went here for drinks, but it was a blast, and by the time I left, the bartender felt like a friend. Super cool for after work, cozy bar for a cold winter night. I sampled some of the pizza, and it was GREAT. I look forward to returning for the food.

31.description: Picture eating delicious Italian food inside an old train car with lights strung across the ceiling, candles and old books beautifully arranged, and fresh flowers on your table. It's what dreams are made of. I'd put this location at the top of my list for romantic, intimate dinners, or a perfect place to have a dinner with a group of girlfriends. The bruschetta and ravioli are my favorite and I couldn't recommend them enough!

34.description: Food was pretty tasty. The best part by far is the ambiance. We sat in an old train car and I thought it was a great place for a romantic date. The staff had clearly built relationships with customers who come often. There's also a bar area that's filled with people as the offices empty out. A very different vibe from the train car, but there's something for everyone.

16.description: Went back for dinner today, got the same order as last time was equally good.The groupon i had expired and our server  Mante threw in free dessert(tiramisu) to makeup, which was a very nice gesture!!

13.description: Couldn't chew the Calimari. Caesar salad was placed on top of hot Calimari during delivery. Watery dressing and wilted lettuce....awful waste of money.

11.description: Just had dinner here, the ambiance is a bit confused, half of it is a very noisy bar and the other half in a quiet train car with romantic lighting. Onto the food:(1) We received fresh shredded cheese, oil and bread upon sitting down which was as expected, delicious. (2) For appetizers, I had caprese salad which was an enormous portion, easily big enough for two people. My bf got the calamari which was also an enormous portion. Between the two, we preferred the caprese.(3) For main course, I ordered the Linguine Spinachi which included mushrooms, spinach, sun-dried tomatoes, garlic oil & pesto. It wasn't what I expected at all - very strong spinach flavor, not the best. My bf ordered the Rigatoni Paesano with Italian sausage, broccoli & mushrooms in a tomato-basil sauce with mozzarella cheese. It was considerably better than my dish.This place was way over priced for the quality of food. The service was good and the portions were huge. However, I don't think I'll be going back. As a side note, parking is a nightmare. There are only about 10 street spots which are always taken and the garage is extremely overpriced.

39.description: Love the setting, great wine, and wonderful food.  The food was fairly traditional, full of flavor, and not too rich.  I'll be back the next time I'm in Chicago.

37.description: We went as full price clients, forgetting there were deals on yelp and living social. First impression was a bunch of people crowding door at bar and that it smelled musty. We were seated in the train part where there was no one else. Empty. Our service was good and server was helpful. We had an affordable bottle of wine and each had an entree. Bill was over $100 and was it worth it? Maybe. Husband had risotto which had way too much garlic. Mom had some sort of cremy chicken dish, and I haf lasagna. Food was good.

0.description: Three of us arrived at about 7:00 pm on a Friday night.  The bar and restaurant were busy but we were told we'd be seated within 10 minutes.  True to promise we were seated in a quieter area from the bar, as requested.  I talked my vegan order over with the waiter and got penne pasta with marinara.  It was delicious!  So fresh!  We will definitely be back!!!

38.description: Your response is another example of your exemplary rudeness. We did in fact initially order two entrees and two deserts because there were no limitations listed in the groupon but changed it to 4 entrees after your server was whining about how the restaurant wasn't making any money off the groupons. And we showed you that we had paid for the groupon before ordering- that's what a receipt is. The real reason you did not ask us to leave was because your pathetic dining room was empty. And no answer to the charge that the bar patrons were yelling throughout our dinner? I guess twenty years of being in business is exactly why you have to offer groupons to drum up business any way that you can.

51.description: Pretty decent food and a fun location. Kind of weird because when you walk in it seems like a bar but you go in the back and there's this sort of box-car feel. I enjoyed the food - it was big portions - and it was fairly reasonably priced, but I didn't think it was outstanding. That being said its a perfectly fine place to go when you want some decent food and a nice waitstaff.

27.description: The food is TERRIBLE. Yes, it's in an old train car, which is kind of cool, but the food is downright awful. The spinach linguini was bland and had no flavor. There was supposed to be pesto in this dish, but there definitely was none. My girlfriend had to douse it in hot pepper, salt, and black pepper to give it any hint of flavor, but it was still bad. The gnocchi with classic ragu sauce tasted way way too buttery inside. I also believe they recently increased their prices quite a bit, but I'm not sure about this. Regardless, the food is way overpriced for the quality. I kind of had a feeling that the food was going to be bad in a restaurant located right off the entrance to 290. The place was also DEAD when we were there during DINNERTIME ON A SATURDAY EVENING- another ominous sign. We had leftovers, but it was so bad that we didn't even want to take them with or bother finishing the food- that's a first.

32.description: Food was good. Came with a 10$ for 20$ Groupon by myself for lunch (that way, I can get the most expensive thing on the menu for 10, lol). I had the Veal Saltimbocca (which was, the most expensive @ 18.95). It was very tasty; the side of pasta al olgio was yummy too.The only weird thing was them using shredded Parmesan for the bread/oil appetizer, instead of the usual grated Parmesan. The bread also wasn't the best.Good food, cool ambiance in the train car.

54.description: sat in the train part with my homeboy after work 4 dinner. there was only 2 other parties there so it wasnt crowded or busy at all. i ordered fettucine pasta with shrimp and spinach & he had the cheese & spinach ravioli. i actually liked his order better than mine but both were pretty delicious. our waiter was nice but couldve been a bit more attentive. regardless, we would both go back cuz the food was tasty.

48.description: Very good food! Came here may times for weekday lunch. Great service (not as bad as I saw in other reviews) Food came fast even during busy hours.Ordered their chicken & mushroom/ chicken pasta for few times. very tasty.

44.description: This place is always interesting.  It's a whore-fest in the bar area (think old traders with too much money and chicks short on brain cells).  Then, you walk through this mess into one of the most romantic dining areas available in the area - it's an old train car that is dimly lit.  The service is fairly professional in the train car, but if you want to have some tits rubbed in your face on the way out, just stop in the bar area.  Also, they are always running deals - Groupon, Yelp, PBS, so be sure to pick one up before you go.  Outie!

24.description: The food was bland/tasteless, the bread brought out was stale. We ordered fried calamari,  chicken fettuccine, a pizza with chicken and spinach and a pasta with shrimp/rice. Waiter was not great,  the waiters helper was amazing though, never once had to ask to have my water refilled, it was always topped and had a change of napkins before we even asked, props to him.I had purchased the groupon special. I paid with my credit card. The waiter increased the price on everything slightly and automatically put himself 18% gratuity for a party of two. Which from my understanding is only done on large parties and optional depending on the service received for small parties.
